GitHub Copilot (GitHub Copilot) GitHub Actions (GitHub, Inc.) Python (Microsoft) Useful links Python Miniconda Documentation Google Colab How to use this repository Below are the steps you need to follow: Create a GitHub account if you don’t have one. Fork this repository to your account. Enable the Issues tab: Go to the Settings tab and check the Issues option. Add your professor as a collaborator: Go to the Settings tab and add their GitHub username in the Collaborators section. Install python: Download Source Code & WWW GitHub repo WWW Where can I find the problems? Please visit the Mathematics Physics Lectures website. Physics Mathematics Discret Mathematics

docs.text: Problem 1 Theoretical Foundation Equations of Motion: A Fundamental Approach Projectile motion can be described by breaking it into horizontal and vertical components. According to Newton’s Second Law: 𝐹 ⃗ = 𝑚 𝑎 ⃗ F =m a where 𝐹 ⃗ F represents force, 𝑚 m is mass, and 𝑎 ⃗ a is acceleration. Horizontal Motion: Constant Velocity Neglecting air resistance, no horizontal force acts on the projectile. Thus, the horizontal velocity remains constant: 𝑣 𝑥 = 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) v x ​ =v 0 ​ cos(θ) The horizontal displacement over time 𝑡 t is given by: 𝑥 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 )   𝑡 x(t)=v 0 ​ cos(θ)t Vertical Motion: Accelerated Motion Due to Gravity In the vertical direction, gravity provides a constant acceleration downward ( 𝑔 g): 𝑎 𝑦 = − 𝑔 a y ​ =−g Integrating the acceleration, we obtain the vertical velocity: 𝑣 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) − 𝑔 𝑡 v y ​ (t)=v 0 ​ sin(θ)−gt and the vertical displacement: 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 )   𝑡 − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 y(t)=v 0 ​ sin(θ)t− 2 1 ​ gt 2 Time of Flight The time of flight is determined by when the projectile returns to the ground (i.e., when 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 0 y(t)=0). Setting the vertical displacement equation equal to zero gives: 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 )   𝑡 − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 = 0 v 0 ​ sin(θ)t− 2 1 ​ gt 2 =0 Factoring out 𝑡 t: 𝑡 ( 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 ) = 0 t(v 0 ​ sin(θ)− 2 1 ​ gt)=0 This results in two solutions: 𝑡 0 t=0 (at launch) 𝑡 2 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑔 t= g 2v 0 ​ sin(θ) ​ (total time of flight) Horizontal Range 𝑅 R The horizontal range is found by substituting the total time of flight into the horizontal displacement equation: 𝑅 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) ⋅ 2 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑔 R=v 0 ​ cos(θ)⋅ g 2v 0 ​ sin(θ) ​ Using the trigonometric identity sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) = 2 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) sin(2θ)=2sin(θ)cos(θ): 𝑅 𝑣 0 2 sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) 𝑔 R= g v 0 2 ​ sin(2θ) ​ Key Insights Maximum Range: Occurs when 𝜃 = 45 ∘ θ=45 ∘ Symmetry: Launching at 𝜃 θ and ( 90 ∘ − 𝜃 ) (90 ∘ −θ) results in the same range. Dependence on Initial Velocity: The range scales with the square of the initial speed ( 𝑅 ∝ 𝑣 0 2 R∝v 0 2 ​ ). Thus, doubling 𝑣 0 v 0 ​ quadruples the range. Gravity’s Effect: Larger gravitational acceleration reduces the range ( 𝑅 ∝ 1 𝑔 R∝ g 1 ​ ). Analysis of the Range Effect of the Angle of Projection The formula 𝑅 𝑣 0 2 sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) 𝑔 R= g v 0 2 ​ sin(2θ) ​ shows that 𝑅 R is maximized when sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) sin(2θ) is at its maximum value, which occurs at 𝜃 = 45 ∘ θ=45 ∘ . In addition, complementary angles (e.g., 30 ∘ 30 ∘ and 60 ∘ 60 ∘ ) yield the same range. Effects of Initial Velocity and Gravity Initial Velocity: Since 𝑅 ∝ 𝑣 0 2 R∝v 0 2 ​ , a small increase in speed leads to a substantial increase in range. High-speed projectiles travel much further. Gravity: A stronger gravitational field (larger 𝑔 g) results in a shorter range. For example, on the Moon (with 𝑔 ≈ 1.6   m/s 2 g≈1.6m/s 2 ), the range would be significantly greater than on Earth. Practical Applications Sports Soccer & Baseball: Players often aim for launch angles close to 45 ∘ 45 ∘ to maximize distance. Basketball: Shots might use higher arcs for better chances of scoring. Engineering & Ballistics Artillery: Designing trajectories for maximum range usually involves angles near 45 ∘ 45 ∘ . Aerospace: Projectile motion under varying gravitational fields is critical in planning spacecraft trajectories. Uneven Terrain When the landing height differs from the launch height, the vertical motion is modeled as: 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑦 0 + 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 )   𝑡 − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 y(t)=y 0 ​ +v 0 ​ sin(θ)t− 2 1 ​ gt 2 Setting 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑦 𝑓 y(t)=y f ​ and solving for 𝑡 t using the quadratic formula allows adjustment of the range calculation: 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 − 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑡 + ( 𝑦 0 − 𝑦 𝑓 ) = 0 2 1 ​ gt 2 −v 0 ​ sin(θ)t+(y 0 ​ −y f ​ )=0 The horizontal range becomes: 𝑅 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) ⋅ 𝑡 landing R=v 0 ​ cos(θ)⋅t landing ​ Air Resistance and Wind Effects Air Resistance: The drag force on a projectile is given by: 𝐹 drag = 1 2 𝐶 𝑑 𝜌 𝐴 𝑣 2 F drag ​ = 2 1 ​ C d ​ ρAv 2 This force reduces the range and alters the trajectory shape, necessitating numerical simulations for accurate predictions. Wind Effects: A tailwind increases the range, while a headwind decreases it. Crosswinds may alter the lateral position of the projectile. Computational Modeling: Python Simulation The following Python script simulates the range versus angle for an ideal projectile (ignoring air resistance and wind). It plots the projectile range as a function of the launch angle. python Copy Edit import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt Constants g = 9.81 # Acceleration due to gravity (m/s^2) v0 = 20.0 # Initial velocity (m/s) Angle range from 0 to 90 degrees angles_deg = np.linspace(0, 90, 500) angles_rad = np.radians(angles_deg) Range equation: R = (v0^2 * sin(2θ)) / g ranges = (v0**2 * np.sin(2 * angles_rad)) / g Find maximum range and corresponding angle max_range = np.max(ranges) optimal_angle = angles_deg[np.argmax(ranges)] Plotting plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) plt.plot(angles_deg, ranges, label=f'v0 = {v0} m/s', color='royalblue') plt.axvline(optimal_angle, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Max at {optimal_angle:.1f}°') plt.title('Projectile Range vs Launch Angle') plt.xlabel('Launch Angle (degrees)') plt.ylabel('Range (meters)') plt.grid(True) plt.legend() plt.tight_layout() plt.show() Limitations and Realistic Considerations Assumptions of the Ideal Model No air resistance: The simple model neglects drag. Flat terrain: The formula assumes the launch and landing heights are equal. Constant gravity: Gravity is treated as uniform. No wind: External forces such as wind are not included. Extending the Model For more realistic scenarios, consider the following enhancements: Air Resistance: Introduce a drag force and solve the differential equations using numerical methods (e.g., Euler or Runge-Kutta methods). Wind Effects: Include wind as a variable force in the simulation. Uneven Terrain: Modify the model to account for differences in launch and landing heights. Conclusion This analysis of projectile motion reveals how the range depends on the launch angle, initial velocity, and gravitational acceleration. While the ideal model—with its clear mathematical relationships—provides a strong basis for understanding projectile motion, real-world conditions such as air resistance, wind, and uneven terrain necessitate more complex modeling. By combining theoretical derivations with computational simulations in Python, one gains valuable insights into both the simplicity and the complexity of projectile dynamics. These principles find application in fields ranging from sports and engineering to aerospace science.

docs.text: plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) plt.plot(angles_deg, ranges, label=f'v0 = {v0} m/s', color='royalblue') plt.axvline(optimal_angle, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Max at {optimal_angle:.1f}°') plt.title('Projectile Range vs Launch Angle') plt.xlabel('Launch Angle (degrees)') plt.ylabel('Range (meters)') plt.grid(True) plt.legend() plt.tight_layout() plt.show() Limitations and Realistic Considerations Assumptions of the Ideal Model No air resistance: The simple model neglects drag. Flat terrain: The formula assumes the launch and landing heights are equal. Constant gravity: Gravity is treated as uniform. No wind: External forces such as wind are not included. Extending the Model For more realistic scenarios, consider the following enhancements: Air Resistance: Introduce a drag force and solve the differential equations using numerical methods (e.g., Euler or Runge-Kutta methods). Wind Effects: Include wind as a variable force in the simulation. Uneven Terrain: Modify the model to account for differences in launch and landing heights. Conclusion This analysis of projectile motion reveals how the range depends on the launch angle, initial velocity, and gravitational acceleration. While the ideal model—with its clear mathematical relationships—provides a strong basis for understanding projectile motion, real-world conditions such as air resistance, wind, and uneven terrain necessitate more complex modeling. By combining theoretical derivations with computational simulations in Python, one gains valuable insights into both the simplicity and the complexity of projectile dynamics. These principles find application in fields ranging from sports and engineering to aerospace science.
